title: 108_s1916
content:
The Act titled "Military Survivor Benefits Improvement Act of 2003" provides full SBP survivor benefits for surviving spouses over the age of 62. The Act "Military Survivor Benefits Improvement Act of 2003" increases the basic annuity to 55 percent for certain months starting from September 2014. This applies to reserve-component annuity and special-eligibility annuity as well. The Act "Military Survivor Benefits Improvement Act of 2003" increases the basic annuity to 55 percent for certain months starting from September 2014. Section 1457(b) of title 10, United States Code, is amended to phase out the supplemental annuity by specifying decreasing percentages and limits for computation. Effective on October 1, 2014, the Military Survivor Benefits Improvement Act of 2003 repealed the program by amending chapter 73 of title 10, United States Code. Annuities under section 1450 of title 10 were recomputed each month to reflect the new percentage applicable for that month. The Military Survivor Benefits Improvement Act of 2003 repealed the program on October 1, 2014, amending chapter 73 of title 10, United States Code. Annuities under section 1450 of title 10 were recomputed monthly to reflect the new percentage. The Secretary of Defense will ensure retired pay reductions for supplemental survivor annuities are adjusted as required by the amendments. Recomputation of annuities applies to specific months in October 2005, 2008, and 2014. Retired pay under section 1460 of title 10, United States Code, is adjusted to meet the objectives in subsection (b) of that section. The Survivor Benefit Plan open enrollment period begins on October 1, 2005. During the open enrollment period starting on October 1, 2005, eligible retired or former members can elect to participate in the Survivor Benefit Plan or the Supplemental Survivor Benefit Plan if not currently enrolled and entitled to retired pay. (A) Retired or former members under 60 years of age are entitled to retired pay under chapter 1223 of title 10, United States Code. 
(B) Persons making elections under the Survivor Benefit Plan are treated as providing either a standard annuity or reserve-component annuity. 
(c) Participants in the Survivor Benefit Plan can elect to increase coverage during the open enrollment period. During the open enrollment period, participants in the Survivor Benefit Plan can choose to increase coverage by opting for a higher base amount or providing annuity coverage for their spouse or former spouse. Additionally, eligible individuals can elect to participate in the Supplemental Survivor Benefit Plan. During the open enrollment period, participants in the Survivor Benefit Plan can increase coverage by opting for a higher base amount or providing annuity coverage for their spouse or former spouse. Eligible individuals can also elect to participate in the Supplemental Survivor Benefit Plan. However, there are limitations on eligibility for certain SBP participants based on annuity computation under specific sections of the law. Participants can waive the right to have their annuity computed under the specified section during the open enrollment period, with such election being irrevocable. Participants in the Survivor Benefit Plan can make elections in writing during the open enrollment period, with the election being effective the following month. The open enrollment period for these elections started on October 1, 2005. If a person dies within two years of making an election under this section, the election becomes void and any reduction in retired pay will be paid in a lump sum to the deceased person's beneficiary. Certain provisions of law apply to elections made under this section. The Secretary of Defense may require an additional premium for these elections. The Secretary of Defense determines the amount for Survivor Benefit Plan elections based on regulations. The report on the open season for the plan includes implementation plans, cost estimates, and any legislative recommendations.
